I’d like to thank the developers of Icarus.

I was looking for a survival game with an open world that truly challenges the player.
As an adult, I don’t have endless hours to spend grinding — which is unfortunately the norm in this kind of games. The sense of progression and character development in Icarus is a masterpiece.
The fact that the game offers a skill tree providing meaningful support for a solo players is something truly special. It’s not overcomplicated, rather subtle and perfectly balanced.
You don’t suddenly become a superhero, but you do feel well and fair treated if you play solo. 

The atmosphere of the world is outstanding.
That first dusk on the planet, the distant sounds, the whispering wind, and the echoes of unknown creatures - all of it creates a powerful sense of isolation. You genuinely feel surrounded by something unknown and unpredictable.

The planet doesn’t make survival easy — the environment is harsh, and the wildlife can be hostile.
Get too close, and you’ll be attacked. Yet those same creatures can also be tamed, becoming your companions as you venture farther from the safety of your base.

From a crouched, frightened survivor clutching a wooden spear, you evolve into an explorer whom planning, logistics, and resource management become essential.

The lore and the world itself form a cohesive whole — every anomaly and strange occurrence simply fits.

It’s a wonderful adventure that can fill many evenings.

Once again, a big thank you to the developers. I wholeheartedly recommend Icarus to anyone seeking an open-world survival experience that is unpredictable, genuinely challenging, yet ultimately fulfilling and rewarding.

Purchased when on sale and feel like I got my money's worth. I would have played this a lot longer if some of the missions weren't so tedious and aggravating. I would have gladly bought DLC expansions, but was afraid the tedious missions would be the same and didn't want to punish myself any further.

Exploring the Olympus map:
I really enjoyed exploring the map, but was disappointed that there were only a few biome types especially when snooping through the tech tiers and seeing items from places mentioning swamp and volcanic in the description. This led me to believe we would be encountering these places on the Olympus map, but as far as I could tell these are DLC locations. The biomes you do have don't vary much in appearance and maybe might offer you some additional resources or animal encounters. 

Leveling up your character:
Leveling seemed to happen quickly in multiplayer. We were unlocking skills and tech tiers so quickly it was a little overwhelming so we spent much of our early game building a base and crafting new workbenches and storage. This is what mostly drove us to explore as we needed resources not found in our immediate area. Due to this, we weren't running the missions very much, which partly led to us feeling a bit let down and frustrated when we did engage with the operational missions.

Weather system:
On the whole, I thought the weather system was really, really cool. I don't want to spoil too much for new players, but seeing how things reacted to weather was super exciting for us. In the long run, as you level up, it feels like it can become tedious as you are heading out to do something and a storm hits causing you a delay if you are trying to avoid it.

Food & Water:
Food is everywhere and that's a good thing because spoil times happen quickly since it's hard to preserve items. You have to salt everything not in a jar to keep it longer, and even then it goes quickly. There are enough water sources as long as you have the means to clean it.

Missions: 
This is one of my biggest gripes. Missions are not always well thought out and start in static areas so they don't take into account where you are at on the map when they are activated. On a dedicated server, we spawned in the river area of the map and not the forest. Most of the missions were so far away from our base it became tedious constantly traveling there to complete the earlier missions. We ended up setting up a second base to avoid running across the map with constant stamina drains with slower animals (buffalo).

The missions can be frustrating and the objectives aren't always clear. For the "build an outpost" type missions, you don't understand you are practically going to build another base (ridiculous) since they require nails or ingots for some of the workstations they ask you to craft. Or you travel to a start area and are sent to several other areas of the map. Most of these are OK, but sometimes they send you back to another area you just came from so there could be a lot of backtracking to complete their objectives. A couple of other missions closed off pass throughs to other biomes that we normally had open (avalanche) making that pass through completely useless.  Also, and this was huge, the mission pods can sometimes land IN YOUR BASE, which causes damage on takeoff. Toward the end of the Olympus map, it felt like we were only logging in to complete missions in hopes of unlocking some additional content and it wasn't super engaging after being led around the map.

DLC's:
If I love a game, I don't mind spending the additional money on content if it's something I want. I did pick up the creature comforts DLC for this game and enjoyed it while we played. My biggest gripe about the DLC's? Throughout gameplay you constantly come across DLC items and it makes you think you are going to encounter this stuff on Olympus, but you're not. So there is a big tease for bosses and items you are never going to encounter or craft because you don't have have access to those areas. You don't understand this at first and are soon disappointed that you beat this creature and can't craft all of the items you think you are going to because it's not available to you. In that case, I would rather you not show it to me.

Updates: 
The game receives weekly updates which is impressive. Most of the updates are not for issues on Olympus and seem to pertain to DLC content. There are the occasional items for Olympus, but the list of fixes/changes/added content seem mostly for stuff that you are not going to encounter in the base game and seem to pertain to DLC items.

Overall:
I enjoyed most of the gameplay we had until we started trying to finish the operational missions. It feels like Olympus could do with more engaging content and not rinse repeat missions, and an easier way to travel around the map like a fast travel or teleporter ( you have all this amazing tech) if the missions are never going to take into account where you are located on the map for open world gameplay. I did not experience the mission based game play so cannot speak to experience with that. Because I enjoyed most of the game, I am going to recommend the game, but hope that the devs improve the missions so they are more accessible and engaging for the open world players.

Others could play differently. You can start a mission on a whole new world and fight for survival with friends. That style of game play is almost unrecognizable from mind but both are perfectly possible in this game. 

My only complaint is that the directions aren't clear at the beginning. I had to go online to understand the difference between Open World, Missions, and Out Posts and I wasted a LOT of time on a mission when it would have been beneficial. Once you get started though, it's pretty easy to figure out what to do. 

I will add, however, that there are quality of life problems. I wish I could add spots to the map much earlier in game. I hate the idea that I'm a space traveler with inter-stellar communication but I haven't figured out how to make a charcoal mark on a map. Seems pretty basic. I also wish there was some sort of teleport between bases. Some people may enjoy the grind of having to walk or ride everywhere but I'm a busy man with a job and kids. I've played a lot of survival games. It's my favorite genre. I've dumped countless hours into them. This one is one of the better ones I have played. It's been out since 2021 and is still getting regular updates on top of it.

One thing I love is it forces you to explore beyond your base. Resources are finite, at least for the first part of your experience. Finite resources means you have to explore farther and farther out when you need more materials, meaning you explore more of the map and come across new creatures and biomes. (Yes, you can respawn resources with certain Tier 4 technologies, but those are a ways off)

The co-op is a blast. I've been playing mostly with my buddy and it's been a good time the whole time. The game can be a chill building simulator where you and your friends can make a nice base, or you can take on missions together. 

The mission variety is good. You have simple missions which are usually quick and relatively easy, good for farming xp, and you have campaign missions which force you to explore more and more of the map, often sending you far from your base. Some of the campaign missions even unlock new biomes for you.

The game is very pretty. A lot of the views are very picturesque and the landscapes are beautiful. The devs outdid themselves with the aesthetic visuals.

I have a few nitpicks, but nothing serious enough to detract from my enjoyment of the game. (Tamed wolves not having a 'stay' option like the mounts, fishing lures not always working as advertised, non-refrigerated food's overly quick spoil timers)

Overall I would wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys survival games. It gives you the tools to have just a chill base-building experience to survive and thrive, or solid exploration for those who like to get out and do things.

Beware the polar bears!

SO. ESSENTIALLY. If I'm to summarize this game, it's a tightly put together game focused on survival crafter experiences with a roguelite flair. This game is not for normal people. I am not a normal people. 

Originally, the game had not launched with a traditional open world "Do as you please" sandbox style of survival crafter. Instead, and what's still the focus, is the idea that you drop in from orbit to accomplish a contract, then leave the planet. This requires you to drop in with, generally, nothing. Grab rock, bang rock, put rock on stick, unga down the wildlife, drink river water, get dysentery, continue stick and rock and more rock and stick until you wake up with a shotgun. 

What helps set this apart from other games like Enshrouded, is that the gameplay loop is extremely concise. It's not like other games where you have to depopulate the walrus for the one is ten chance for it to drop a factory new taint, where you need seven of them to craft a 5% better hammer to build your furniture faster. This game is FAST, there's very few base materials in any given tech tier. At the stone age you've got abooouuut eight different materials? Half of which is just pick up every bush, rock and tree you can get your hands around. Building a base is SUPER fast, with only mildly finnicky snap mechanics. The resources you DO get are in decently large quantity as well, so it's easy to piece together large, LARGE bases with only a few hours of work. The same cabin I slap together within minutes of each drop would take me /hours/ of grind in games like Runescape: Dragonwilds, Enshrouded, Valheim, or any of these other titles that I love. Even when you're teching up into metallurgics, the materials don't become varied and diverse until way, waaaay later on. It's a little like Factorio or Satisfactory in how materials can feed into new types of materials and become more mechanically interesting. 

The game is F A S T.  You scrounge fast, you build fast, you do your mission, you leave the planet, and everything on the surface gets reset. The game has several ways of trying to convey the idea to you that everything is temporary, don't be careless about stuff, but also learn to let go. Your base won't be there in the next drop, and that's okay. Your longbow that you popped twenty deer with won't be around forever, and that's okay. Pick your next mission, take a breath, dive in. The ACS has money, you won't get any of it staying in orbit. 

I do have some genuine criticisms. The game can be frustrating at times, when the animal spawn mechanics decide to light a polar bear under your ass. You could be having a merry stroll through the woods, when OOPS bear. Even worse is just trying to get through the desert, just point A to point B will see you fending off cougars like a twenty-five year old quarter back in an Applebee's. The amount of wildlife that live their entire lives, going about their own survival and building up nothing but pure HATRED for the player is insane. These critters coexist just fine, I've seen zebra and cougars/hyenas just hangin' out like gators and capybaras, but THE MOMENT one of those silly suited up people creatures show up, OH IT'S ON. They will throw themselves by the dozens into spiked walls just for the mere opporotinity to bite your ankle, it's absurd. 

Beyond the frustration, building is a little jank. It's ALWAYS jank in these games, and I can't expect the same amount of autism spirit bomb levels of detailing that games like Avorion and Vintage Story allow me to get into, but there's lots of pieces that are just... missing? yeah there's pieces straight up missing. Pieces such as the middle roof bit for half roofs, so you can use half blocks to create a nice, gently sloping roof on a house with odd dimensions. Or the wood beams that are diagonal but don't point in one of the four directions. There's also plenty of bizarre grid snap interactions the moment you start using the beams in the first place. The lack of terrain modification... I understand, but it does often lead to dirt poking up through your floor. This has caused me to just raise all my houses off the ground, it works. Also the foritified walls are direcitonal, but I've not seen them actually display their direction, which can lead to instances like the one where I built a wonderful little defensive perimiter wiiiiith all the spikie pointy bits pointed at ME. That... didn't work so well. Tearing down the walls to spin them around lead to me falling into a WWE cage match where every time I defeated the two cougars I was currently fighting, a scorpion, or hyena, or more cougars would just pop out of nowhere and bonzai charge me. I'M JUST TRYING TO WALL. PLEASE. LEAVE ME BE.

[h1] Excellent game, BUT [/h1]

Icarus is a brilliant game, without a doubt. However it does come with its flaws and issues, like any other game. It is an excellent open world sandbox game, that's for sure. However, before you venture onwards. The two biggest issues we found:

[b] Missions: [/b]
The missions and campaigns in open world are questionable. The biggest issue we found is simply the lack of information provided to the player, which often led to frustration rather than enjoyment. A prime example was a mission where we had to go and find a bandit output. Once we got there, the game then informed us we needed to power 10k into a radar - we did not know this, and thus we had to cross the map to get the resources and then go back. Only to then find out we also needed a beacon as well, which resulted in a third trip. So much time was wasted and our enjoyment was at an all time low.  Missions need to be clearer on what needs to be done in advance. 

Mission rewards are also not worth the effort and time you spent. We had to introduce a mod that made the rewards better.

[b] Performance: [/b]
Performance is iffy as the world goes on, I can only assume due to the sheer volume of stuff building up behind the scenes. We noticed our FPS dropping as we played. This is noticeable on Olympus, the later DLC maps seem to be better. But overall, improvement is needed. Running an i7 with a 4070ti on Ultra with DLSS, averaged 200 FPS which lowered down to 100-80 as I played.

ICARUS is a very weird lil' game.
On one hand you have a somewhat complex skill-tree and tech-tree, with roughly a bit more than a dozen different materials you can mine and use but the longer one plays, the faster one realizes that the game's very, very shallow.

There are weird bugs, questionable design choices, a wonky multiplayer but most critical, there's no real sense of progression.

[h2]The Good: [/h2]
+ The open-world is really big. It contains a couple of biomes and they are interconnected via pathways, tunnels, etc.
+ The setting is very interesting, being a prospector on a hostile planet on which the air is toxic.
+ Building is snappy and quite easy to do.
+ Tools and weapons have a clear use but can be used outside of it as well (for example as a weapon).
+ Some graphics, especially for the animals, are quite well-done.

[h2]The Bad: [/h2]
Hoo boy, where to begin...

-- The Multiplayer is glitchy. From fires that continue to burn to weird animation for downed players.
--- There is no sense of progression in the game. You can stay in your starting biome and farm XP till you are max-level and build then build your base. There's no real need to travel, there's no challenge to overcome to unlock the next tier. It's blunt and boring farming.
--- A good part of the game (which might give some sense of progression or danger) is locked behind DLCs that cost over €100+. I don't mind DLCs if they are substantial and are build on top of an already well-made game but ICARUS is not a well-made game and the content of the DLCs is sometimes a bad joke. There are developers who bring out better content updates for free.
-- Animals just feel... artificial? You find all sorts of animals all over a biome and there are no nests, no territorial behaviour, no nothing. They just spawn in and exist and don't feel like part of the ecosystem but just to be a farm for easy food and XP.
-- I honestly don't understand why we have such a massive skill-tree. Are we meant to play the game it with others? Does it try to cater to different playstyles?  I don't fully know because some skills are so niche that you get the feel you need others to be as efficient as possible.
-- The world despite its size, is very bland. It's no fun to discover the 6th cave (that are hidden actually quite well) with a device that is pretty much pointless to figure out where caves are when you simply can look 'em up on the internet. There's just no sense of discovery
-- Survival is easy as cake. There's no challenge anymore during the mid-game. Storms don't feel threatening when it comes to ones base nor person, especially as exploration isn't necessary. Managing oxygen, water and hunger is very easy and even the different debuffs aren't really challenging and remind me strongly of Empyrion Galactic Survival's debuffs.
- The quests and missions just create an appeal, I've tried the first and got bored of it. The rewards and the workshop system feel rather pointless as well. Why would I want a knife, armour, bow, that I cannot easily repair if I can simply craft one out of natural resources, can repair it and have the same effect?

[h2] Conclusion: [/h2]

ICARUS is a survival game that tries to put the player into the shoes of a prospector, doing missions or just roaming around in the open-world, trying to survive. But the core-gameplay is so lacking with no real danger, with no real struggle. While the early-game still shines with the possibilities what one can do, what one has to do to survive, those needs are swiftly met and one simply wonders what is there to do. Exploration is unsatisfying, you find the same resources, fight identical animals and worms, endure the storms that just have another flavour. The tech-tree and skills are locked behind levels that you gain by murdering the fauna and flora, nothing crucial is really tied to exploration as the world is, in fact, empty.
After nearly 18 hours of gameplay I've had my fill of ICARUS and cannot recommend it to anyone seeking a survival experience.

There are bosses, but you only have one boss you can encounter in the base game, with all other bosses being on DLC planets. This will also lock out some materials and certain exotics (this to be used for the workshop items). With that being said, there are plenty of other games that are base building while being more explorative, combat oriented, and in my opinion, entertaining. Doing anything with the workshop or offworld missions is super grindy, and all the other interesting material for the game is locked behind DLCs.

Watch some streams or gameplay videos before you buy the game. The only way to keep truly interested is to buy the DLCs, and the base game itself should be entertaining enough without spending more money.

ICARUS is a very weird lil' game.
On one hand you have a somewhat complex skill-tree and tech-tree, with roughly a bit more than a dozen different materials you can mine and use but the longer one plays, the faster one realizes that the game's very, very shallow.

There are weird bugs, questionable design choices, a wonky multiplayer but most critical, there's no real sense of progression.

[h2]The Good: [/h2]
+ The open-world is really big. It contains a couple of biomes and they are interconnected via pathways, tunnels, etc.
+ The setting is very interesting, being a prospector on a hostile planet on which the air is toxic.
+ Building is snappy and quite easy to do.
+ Tools and weapons have a clear use but can be used outside of it as well (for example as a weapon).
+ Some graphics, especially for the animals, are quite well-done.

[h2]The Bad: [/h2]
Hoo boy, where to begin...

-- The Multiplayer is glitchy. From fires that continue to burn to weird animation for downed players.
--- There is no sense of progression in the game. You can stay in your starting biome and farm XP till you are max-level and build then build your base. There's no real need to travel, there's no challenge to overcome to unlock the next tier. It's blunt and boring farming.
--- A good part of the game (which might give some sense of progression or danger) is locked behind DLCs that cost over €100+. I don't mind DLCs if they are substantial and are build on top of an already well-made game but ICARUS is not a well-made game and the content of the DLCs is sometimes a bad joke. There are developers who bring out better content updates for free.
-- Animals just feel... artificial? You find all sorts of animals all over a biome and there are no nests, no territorial behaviour, no nothing. They just spawn in and exist and don't feel like part of the ecosystem but just to be a farm for easy food and XP.
-- I honestly don't understand why we have such a massive skill-tree. Are we meant to play the game it with others? Does it try to cater to different playstyles?  I don't fully know because some skills are so niche that you get the feel you need others to be as efficient as possible.
-- The world despite its size, is very bland. It's no fun to discover the 6th cave (that are hidden actually quite well) with a device that is pretty much pointless to figure out where caves are when you simply can look 'em up on the internet. There's just no sense of discovery
-- Survival is easy as cake. There's no challenge anymore during the mid-game. Storms don't feel threatening when it comes to ones base nor person, especially as exploration isn't necessary. Managing oxygen, water and hunger is very easy and even the different debuffs aren't really challenging and remind me strongly of Empyrion Galactic Survival's debuffs.
- The quests and missions just create an appeal, I've tried the first and got bored of it. The rewards and the workshop system feel rather pointless as well. Why would I want a knife, armour, bow, that I cannot easily repair if I can simply craft one out of natural resources, can repair it and have the same effect?

[h2] Conclusion: [/h2]

ICARUS is a survival game that tries to put the player into the shoes of a prospector, doing missions or just roaming around in the open-world, trying to survive. But the core-gameplay is so lacking with no real danger, with no real struggle. While the early-game still shines with the possibilities what one can do, what one has to do to survive, those needs are swiftly met and one simply wonders what is there to do. Exploration is unsatisfying, you find the same resources, fight identical animals and worms, endure the storms that just have another flavour. The tech-tree and skills are locked behind levels that you gain by murdering the fauna and flora, nothing crucial is really tied to exploration as the world is, in fact, empty.
After nearly 18 hours of gameplay I've had my fill of ICARUS and cannot recommend it to anyone seeking a survival experience.

I really want to like ICARUS, which is why it pains me that I can’t recommend the game in its current state. The game’s performance is simply too abysmal for me to keep playing.

ICARUS was originally designed to be based on missions, meaning players would drop into the world, complete different objectives and return to the menu. This meant the game didn’t have to keep track of any changes to the world, such as player built structures, felled trees and damaged ores. With the introduction of the open world mode, that’s no longer the case. Since the OW is persistent, every instance has to be saved in its updated state. All this means that the more you build and progress, the harder it gets for the game to keep up, and that’s when major stutters and freezes kick in. This is also present in other survival games like Valheim and Enshrouded, but not nearly to the same extent. I fear the devs would have to rebuild this game from the ground up to truly make it work as an OW experience. Since I doubt that will ever happen, I just don’t see myself coming back to the game.

I’ve done testing on 3 different rigs (RTX 2080 Super&12600K; RX 7800XT&7800X3D; RX 9070XT&7800X3D; 32GB of RAM each), and the issue remained the same. Tweaking settings can bring some level of improvement to the overall framerate, but it doesn’t help with the constant FPS drops.

For those only interested in the missions, this one is  still worth checking out. Those who only want to play OW should probably skip it and save themselves the headache. Props to the devs for still releasing small updates every Friday, but I really wish they’d take a break from adding DLC to focus on improving the performance side of things. Fix your game first, then sell additional content.
